content: The "Urban Jobs Act of 2011" is the short title of this Act. It aims to provide findings and purposes related to urban job creation. Congress finds that one-third of minority youth are unemployed, the labor force participation rate is lower for individuals without a high school diploma, African-American and Hispanic students have a lower graduation rate, and high school dropouts from the class of 2004 will cost the nation over $325 billion in lost wages, taxes, and productivity. High school dropouts from the class of 2004 will cost the Nation over $325 billion in lost wages, taxes, and productivity. Only 52 percent of students in the 50 largest cities in the United States graduate from high school, which is below the national average of 70 percent. Only 52 percent of students in the 50 largest cities in the United States graduate from high school, falling below the national average of 70 percent. High school dropouts earn significantly less over their lifetime compared to graduates, with dropouts earning about $260,000 less than graduates and $1,000,000 less than college graduates. Additionally, a high percentage of prison inmates have not completed high school. High school dropouts earn significantly less over their lifetime compared to graduates and college graduates. Approximately 75 percent of State prison inmates and 59 percent of Federal prison inmates have not completed high school. Increasing the high school completion rate by 1 percent for all men ages 20 to 60 would save the United States $1.4 billion annually in reduced crime costs. According to a recent study, a 10-percent increase in the male high school graduation rate would significantly reduce arrest rates for various crimes. The purpose of this Act is to provide resources to prevent disproportionate incarceration of eligible youth, especially minority youth, and prepare them for entry into society. The Act aims to reduce crime rates, particularly murder and assault, by providing resources to national nonprofit organizations for youth empowerment and employment readiness. SEC. 3. URBAN JOBS PROGRAMS. Amends the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 to include a new section on Urban Jobs Programs. The section aims to provide competitive grants for establishing a feeder system for youth aged 18-24 in urban communities, focusing on out-of-school youth or those involved in the criminal justice system, to help them access education or employment opportunities. The grants aim to prepare eligible youth for entry into employment or education leading to employment, prevent disproportionate incarceration of youth in urban communities, and provide a holistic approach through a national network of community-based affiliates. The Urban Jobs Program, funded under subsection (c), has operated in 25 States continuously for more than 20 years. Recidivism refers to a tendency to return to criminal behavior, while an unsubsidized job is an employment position that pays wages and does not receive public funds. The Urban Jobs Program, funded under subsection (c), provides grants to national intermediaries for comprehensive services to urban youth for employment pathways. The Secretary can award grants to national intermediaries for Urban Jobs Programs that offer services to urban youth for employment or education leading to employment. Eligible intermediaries must submit an application to be considered for the grant. To be eligible for a grant under this subsection, a national intermediary must submit an application with specified grant amount and proposed uses of funds as required by the Secretary.
